comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: The O'Connell monumnent was not moved since '73 though the Loyalists did try to move it one Christmas .  They only managed to shift one of his angels as the Kerryman stood firm above them!!! There are a few other things to look at in this great shot!  The green of the old double decker, the infamous "THING" the flower bed beside the cyclist on the left etc.  A notable omission is there is no Garda traffic pointsman in view at the junction, these were so higgledy piggledy that a Garda was essential to keep things moving and at rush hours it could need two!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Wonder if the infamous "THING" had a nickname as all sculpture/monuments has today? Or was it nickname "the infamous THING"? :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: That's right, it was known as the "THING" and was reviled.  At one time they had boxes for the traffic pointsmen to stand on at either end but they did not work as the Gardai needed to move around to control the several streams of traffic!

comment.author: 24101413@N03
comment._content: I would question the date of 1973, as I lived in Dublin from summer 1972 and don't recall seeing buses in that green livery.  I think it was phased out in the latter part of the 1960s but no doubt there are plenty of bus experts who can clarify this.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/24101413@N03] Thanks, and I hope some bus experts will weigh in on this one. The fashion does look slightly earlier too, but I will absolutely double check the date we have for this photo!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 48073612@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/24101413@N03] 
This is a a wonderful photograph. Referring specificially to 'Irish251'
comments, I would agree about 1973 being questionable. The photograph contains at least 3 Coras Iompair Eireann buses. These are Leyland 'OPD Titans', better known as the 'R' class. The green livery, (which pre-dated CIE) was replaced in 1961 by the 'monstral blue & cream'. Given the then CIE practice of overhauling buses in Inchicore every 3 years, it is unlikely that this livery would have survived in big numbers much beyond 1965/6? 
The bus closest in the picture, (northbound on O Connell St) is almost certainly  a member of the so called 'Bolton Class'  (R291-390)? These buses unlike most of their counterparts were purchased off the shelf by C.I.E. (to Bolton Corporation spec -hence the name!). They were most distinct, in that the upper rear windscreen was split, making them almost unique. This bus has this feature as far as I can see. These were all withdrawn by 1967. If this is indeed a 'Bolton' type?, it would date the photograph pre 1967.

The advertising carried on the buses in the picture is painted directly onto the bodywork. This was the norm. This practice ceased in the early 1960,s when vinyl took over. 

In summary the bus would certainly date the picture pre 1967, but given the overall ambiance I feel it is mid to late 1950,s? The Citroen DS would set another timeline beyond 1955. 

Clearly it is beyond 1955 (by virtue of the Citroen). My guess is the photograph was taken sometime between between 1955-1965, but nearer toward 1955?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/48073612@N04] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/24101413@N03] Wow, when I hoped for a bus expert to weigh in, I really struck it lucky! Thank you for all of this detail... Will see if I can get my hands on a hi-res version of this image, to see if any detail in the photo can elicit a more exact date.

For now, I'm lopping a decade off the date, and changing it to 1963. From the clothing, sunshine, etc. am assuming that June is still safe enough!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/48073612@N04] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/24101413@N03] p.s. should have said earlier, English photographer Richard Tilbrook only visited Ireland in the 1960s and early 1970s, so this can't have been taken any time in the 1950s...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content:

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] Either Belvedere College or O'Connell Schools. O'Connell's had a stag's head on its crest, if it's not a stag's head then perhaps Belvedere?

By 1973 O'Connell Schools no longer used school uniforms some years before that, so if the boy went to O'Connell Schools then the image is definitely pre-1973 - even pre-1970. I started in O'Connell Secondary School in 1972 and at that time no one wore a school uniform.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Belvo wore black blazers and that wee lad has a maroon coloured blazer on.  The more you look at it the more you realise that it is '60's rather than 70's! Caffolla's was either named or had a "Sunshine Cafe" right next to it and that does not appear here.  I remember it well from the late '60's early 70's.

TYPEWRITERS
Dublin Cork Limerick

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content:
Carol, if this is 1963, was it before or after the visit of JFK?
I agree with one or two of the other comments about the actual date of the shot.
Looks earlier than '63 Carol. I was looking at the John Hinde Postcards and trying to decide a time by ; The Model of the Buses;  When the GPO was 'cleaned'; The age of the visible cars/vans; the style of hair; plus the the clothes.
If it was 1963, the Window cleaner is wearing a 'Teddy Boy' hair style, remember The Beatles were already on the rise and due to Play in November of '63 in the Adelphi, I am just wondering if their Hairstyle had arrived when this photo was taken???
I know for a fact that the Blue and cream buses were late 60's early 70's, so this shot is (in my opinion) very much early 60's.
